chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect greater trochanteric pain syndrome?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
The diagnosis of greater trochanteric pain syndrome is made on clinical grounds: 

  • Ask about the location, radiation, nature, and onset of pain, and what aggravates or relieves it.
    • Greater trochanteric pain syndrome typically presents with pain in the area of the greater trochanter that may radiate down the lateral aspect of the thigh. The pain is described as deep, aching, or burning. The onset is usually gradual, but may be sudden.
    • The pain is typically aggravated by physical activity, and is worse at night, especially when lying on the affected side.
  • Assess for the core diagnostic features:
    • Lateral hip pain.
    • Point tenderness adjacent to the greater trochanter.
    • A positive Trendelenburg (single leg stance) test.
  • Examine for point tenderness, and for evidence of pain when muscles and tendons attached to the greater trochanter are put under tension.
    • Tenderness is typically elicited at a point over the gluteus medius tendon or its insertion into the greater trochanter.
    • An antalgic gait is sometimes present — when walking, less time is spent bearing weight on the affected side than on the other.
    • There is often pain on resisted active abduction, resisted internal rotation, and/or resisted external rotation of the hip joint on the affected side.
    • The range of motion of the hip may be limited at the extremes of rotation, abduction, adduction, or flexion.
    • The trochanteric bursae are seldom palpable.
  • Check for associated conditions such as lumbar spine conditions and arthritis of the hip or knee.
  • Exclude other conditions with presentations similar to that of greater trochanteric pain syndrome.
  • Exclude any underlying infection of the bursae.
    • A tender palpable mass, redness, oedema, or warmth around the lateral hip would suggest possible infection.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Physical examination
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• A number of tests are used to diagnose greater trochanteric pain syndrome. The tests put tension on the muscles and tendons attached to the greater trochanter, and include:
    • Trendelenburg (single leg stance) test
      • With the person standing, observe from behind while asking them to lift each foot off the ground in turn.
      • A positive test is the pelvis dipping (rather than staying horizontal or rising slightly) on lifting the unaffected leg.
      • The Trendelenberg test can be positive with any painful hip condition, but may be the single most accurate test for greater trochanteric pain syndrome.
    • Resisted active abduction test
      • With the person lying supine place their hip joints in the neutral position (legs together and straight out). Abduct the affected hip joint by 45 degrees while the person resists the movement. If this is painful, the test is positive.
    • Resisted internal rotation test
      • With the person lying supine, position the affected hip joint at 45 degrees flexion and maximal external rotation. Internally rotate the hip joint while the person resists the movement. If this is painful, the test is positive.
    • Resisted external rotation test
      • With the person lying supine, position the affected hip joint at 45 degrees flexion and maximal internal rotation. Externally rotate the hip joint while the person resists the movement. If this is painful, the test is positive.

[Williams and Cohen, 2009; Watts et al, 2013; Kimpel et al, 2014; Mallow and Nazarian, 2014]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on expert opinion in a systematic review article [Reid, 2015], review articles [Williams and Cohen, 2009; Kimpel et al, 2014; Mallow and Nazarian, 2014], and the medical textbook Oxford Textbook of Rheumatology [Watts et al, 2013].
